instructions: Strictly base all content on provided contextual inputs; do not infer or assume missing data.
Do not invent or hallucinate facts, figures, dates, organizations, geographies, or policies.
If any required information is unavailable, insert a brief statement: 'Information not provided in the context.'
If there is no mention in the context of the targeted population size for the project, asssume the project target the entire population of interest for the designated field context.

Use a formal, objective, and analytical tone. Avoid casual, emotional, or advocacy-oriented language. Present information factually and neutrally, focusing on clarity, precision, and concise explanation of context, needs, risks, implementation, monitoring, and results. Avoid exaggeration, unsupported claims, value judgments, and political statements. Use diplomatic and respectful wording and consistent technical terminology appropriate for peacebuilding, conflict analysis, implementation, risk management, monitoring and evaluation, and results reporting.
Use donor names, never donor IDs.
Use outcome names, never outcome IDs.
Use field_context names, never field_context IDs.
For internal controls, audits, procurement, and financial reporting, apply only standard UN policies and provisions that are explicitly supplied in the inputs; do not create new policies or clauses.
For short administrative fields, provide a very short factual statement (maximum 50 words).
For numeric fields, provide numbers only without units unless specified.
For tables, produce valid GitHub-Flavored Markdown tables; do not add narrative outside table cells.

sections.section_label: IV. Peacebuilding Context and Rationale for Support
sections.instructions: Provide a structured conflict analysis covering root causes, drivers, triggers, risks, and key stakeholders; explain how these elements generate the specific peacebuilding needs addressed by the project; summarize alignment with national and UN strategic frameworks; and briefly describe complementary interventions and strategic gaps. Use evidence-based, gender- and age-responsive analysis and reference consultations and available data. Do not include outputs or activities here.

Summarize the project’s overarching goal and implementation strategy, explain how the approach addresses identified conflict factors, describe the comparative advantages of involved actors, and note key sequencing or localization considerations. Keep concise and analytical.

Express the causal logic using clear IF–THEN statements linking interventions to anticipated outcomes and the overarching peace result. State key assumptions and contextual conditions that must hold for change to occur. Do not introduce activities not present in the design.

sections.section_label: V.C Key Project Components (Outcomes and Outputs)
sections.instructions: Provide a narrative description of the project’s outcomes and outputs, highlighting intended institutional and behavioral changes, gender and age considerations, and critical sequencing. Avoid duplicating tables; keep this as a succinct overview tied to the conflict analysis and theory of change.

Define geographic scope and selection criteria; describe stakeholders and beneficiary groups with sex- and age-disaggregated targets where available; include marginalized groups; and outline engagement modalities for institutions, media, and civil society. Address Do No Harm and incentives for participation.

Describe the implementation team (positions, roles, funding share), coordination and oversight arrangements, and mechanisms to ensure adequate gender or youth expertise. Reference convening/coordination functions and readiness to commence implementation.

Provide a concise narrative on contextual, operational, fiduciary, safeguarding, and political risks; describe how risks will be monitored and mitigated using conflict sensitivity and Do No Harm principles; and note any triggers requiring adaptive management.

Describe baseline, data sources, indicator tracking (including sex- and age-disaggregation), roles and frequency, feedback mechanisms, learning and adaptive management, and evaluation plans. Allocate 5–7% of the project budget to M&E and include provision for independent evaluation if applicable.

sections.section_label: VI.D Project Exit Strategy and Sustainability
sections.instructions: Explain how results will be sustained after project completion, including institutionalization, capacity strengthening, handover plans, and any follow-on financing pathways. Keep specific and actionable.

Summarize rationale for major cost categories (staffing, travel, consultancies, grants, materials/equipment ≤15% unless justified, vehicles if any), and indicate the proportion and justification for GEWE allocations.
